overview.title: NIH Human Virome Program
overview.description: The NIH Human Virome Program (HVP) is a comprehensive research initiative aimed at characterizing the human viromeâ€”the collection of all viruses that inhabit the human body. The program seeks to understand how these viruses interact with human cells, the microbiome, and the immune system in both health and disease.

mission.statement: To comprehensively characterize the human virome and elucidate its role in human health and disease.
goals: Develop standardized methods for virome detection and characterization
Create reference datasets of the human virome across diverse populations
Investigate virome-host interactions in health and disease contexts
Build collaborative infrastructure for virome research
Train the next generation of virome scientists

funding.details: The program funds Virome Characterization Centers (VCCs) and Functional Studies projects to establish a comprehensive catalog of viruses found in or on the human body and to understand their impact on human health.

leadership.working_group: The NIH HVP Working Group comprises scientific leaders from multiple NIH Institutes and Centers, representing diverse expertise in virology, microbiology, and human biology.

centers.name: Virome Characterization Centers (VCCs)
centers.description: Major research centers focused on comprehensive virome profiling across diverse human populations and body sites

centers.name: Functional Studies Projects
centers.description: Targeted research projects investigating specific aspects of human virome biology and virus-host interactions

centers.name: Consortium Organization and Data Collaboration Center (CODCC)
centers.description: Coordination hub for administrative activities, data management, and cross-consortium collaboration

expected_outcomes: Comprehensive catalog of human-associated viruses across diverse populations
New tools for viral discovery and functional characterization
Insights into virome's role in human health and disease
Open data resources for the broader scientific community
scientific_impact.significance: This program represents the first coordinated, large-scale effort to systematically characterize the human virome across diverse populations and body sites. The insights gained will transform our understanding of the role viruses play in human biology and provide new paradigms for diagnosing, treating, and preventing viral-associated diseases.

resources.publications: An growing collection of scientific publications from program researchers that will be maintained in the NIH HVP Publications Database
